Line 5: Line 5:
'''James Patrick Cannon''' ([[1890]]-[[1974]]) was an [[United States|American]] [[Communism|Communist]] and [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] leader. Cannon was the founding leader of the [[Socialist Workers Party (United States)|Socialist Workers Party]].
'''James Patrick Cannon''' ([[1890]]-[[1974]]) was an [[United States|American]] [[Communism|Communist]] and [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] leader. Cannon was the founding leader of the [[Socialist Workers Party (United States)|Socialist Workers Party]].
â
Born in [[Rosedale, Kansas]], James P. Cannon was first a member of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] and then of the [[Socialist Party of America]].
+
Born in [[Rosedale, Kansas]], James P. Cannon was first a member of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW) and then of the [[Socialist Party of America]]. He was personally trained by [[Bill Haywood]], a prominent IWW leader.[http://reds.linefeed.org/bios/cannon.html]
Cannon opposed [[World War I]] from an [[internationalism (politics)|internationalist]] position and rallied to the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]]. In [[1919]], he became a founding member of the Workers (Communist) Party (now known as [[Communist Party USA]]) and was part of its leadership from its earliest days, serving as Party Chairman from 1919 to 1928, a position that was actually secondary to that of [[general secretary]].
Cannon opposed [[World War I]] from an [[internationalism (politics)|internationalist]] position and rallied to the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]]. In [[1919]], he became a founding member of the Workers (Communist) Party (now known as [[Communist Party USA]]) and was part of its leadership from its earliest days, serving as Party Chairman from 1919 to 1928, a position that was actually secondary to that of [[general secretary]].
